newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: STIC in US$11 mln China health venture.
newsitem.headline: STIC in US$11 mln China health venture.

text.p: Singapore Technologies Industrial Corp (STIC) said on Wednesday it was investing US$11 million in partnership with a Canadian company to develop the first private international hospital in Beijing.

The investment, through InterHealth Canada (China) Inc (ICCI) in which STIC has a 50 percent stake, will also be used to develop a network of supporting clinics in various Chinese cities, STIC said in a statement.

It said ICCI had entered a joint venture agreement with two Chinese partners, one of which was state-owned Beijing Comprehensive Investment Co, to set up a company called Beijing Toronto International Hospital.
ICCI would have a 51 percent equity stake in the joint venture company, with the Chinese partners holding the remaining 49 percent.
The 250-bed hospital would provide medical services targeted at the expatriate community of over 200,000 in and around Beijing, as well as high income Chinese nationals, it said.
Construction of the hospital would begin in the second half of this year.
The first phase, due to be completed by end-1998, would cost US$29 million and include 60 beds and key hospital services. The hospital is expected to be fully operational by end 2000.
